awd_titl_txt: Social experience: effects on auditory filtering through a serotonergic mechanism
awd_abstract_narration:
In addition to its well-known roles in regulating mood and appetite, the chemical serotonin plays an important role in the response of the brain to social interaction. Despite this, very little is known about its role in a crucial type of social behavior, communication. In their past work, the researchers have shown that serotonin modifies auditory responses to communication calls in mice, and that social partners trigger these increases in serotonin in the auditory system. In other regions of the brain, the serotonergic system itself is heavily influenced by past social experience. With this rationale, the researchers hypothesize that social experience changes the role of the serotonergic system in auditory processing. They will test this idea by measuring how housing mice individually or in social groups affects the way that the serotonergic system interacts with the auditory system. This work will explore a process fundamental to communication: how sensory systems adapt to features of the social environment like social history, with implications for how animals respond to their social partners. The work will also serve as a springboard for a local K-12 outreach program in which undergraduates present interactive lessons on themes of communication and sensory systems.

The social experience hypothesis will be tested in male and female mice, which are increasingly studied models of vocal communication. Mice also demonstrate highly conserved serotonergic function in auditory regions compared with other vertebrates. The specific objectives of the proposed work are to examine the effect of group versus individual housing on three features of serotonin-auditory interactions in the inferior colliculus (IC), a mammalian auditory midbrain nucleus. 1) The first of these is the anatomy of the serotonergic system within the IC. This will be accomplished by measuring the density of immunohistochemically labeled serotonergic fibers. 2) A second feature is the transient serotonergic response to social interactions. This will be measured locally in the IC of behaving animals using carbon fiber voltammetry. 3) A final feature is the serotonergic regulation of the activation of the c-fos transcriptional pathway by social interaction, which will be explored by inducing systemic release or depletion of serotonin. These studies will provide a framework of how social experience creates plasticity in auditory-serotonin interactions at multiple levels of organization, generating testable hypotheses on the downstream consequences of such plasticity for neural encoding and perception.

por.por_cntn:
Prior experience is an important lens through which animals perceive current social interactions. For social animals, a foundational experience in juvenile life that influences communication in adulthood is whether the social environment is rich or isolated. Little is known about the mechanisms through which social isolation influences processing in the sensory brain regions, like the auditory system, that respond to communication signals. The overall goal of the award was to explore the influence of juvenile social isolation on the interaction between central auditory brain regions and the serotonergic system, a neurochemical system important to sensory processing and also the brain?s response to social isolation. Specific objectives of the project were to assess the effect of juvenile social isolation on the anatomical and functional aspects of serotonin-auditory interactions, in particular: 1) the density of projections from serotonergic neurons to the auditory system, 2) the activity of serotonergic neurons during social interaction, and 3) the responses of auditory neurons to the direct manipulation of serotonin. These objectives were accomplished in mice, which can adapt to a range of social environments and have a well-studied system of social vocalizations. The manipulation of the social environment was accomplished by simply housing mice alone or with another mouse for a period of a month beginning after weaning.

              Social isolation influenced serotonin-auditory interactions at all three of these levels. Isolation decreased the densities of serotonergic axons in the inferior colliculus (IC), an auditory center in the midbrain which responds selectively to some types of social vocalizations. Fewer serotonergic neurons in mice that experienced isolation showed a response to social interaction, as measured through expression of an activity-dependent gene product, cFos. These findings are consistent with a weakened regulation by the serotonergic system. In contrast to this diminished input, IC neurons showed an enhanced response to increasing serotonin directly with a serotonin-releasing drug, fenfluramine. The same drug had no effect in animals housed socially, so that manipulation of the serotonergic system and housing condition interacted with each other. Several of the effects of isolation occurred only in female mice or were more pronounced in females than males, suggesting that the regulation of auditory processing is more sensitive to the social environment in female than in male mice. Together, these findings suggest that social isolation changes the dynamics of serotonin-auditory interactions, with a lower baseline of serotonergic regulation, but a stronger response to serotonin release during relevant contexts such as during social interaction or in response to stressors.                

These findings identify the serotonergic system as an important intermediary between social experience and the regulation of sensory processing, consistent with the hypothesis that social experience can affect the perception of vocal signals. From a broader perspective, this work emphasizes the importance of extra-auditory inputs to auditory brain regions, and their role in conveying information related to the behavioral context. These types of mechanisms can fine-tune sensory processing to optimize information extraction under different conditions. Animals like mice live within social environments that range from overcrowded to depauperate. Plasticity in regulatory mechanisms such as the serotonergic system can allow adaptation to different social conditions in adulthood, depending on conditions mice experience as juveniles. In the future, the findings of this study could underlie work on the effects of isolation on the social regulation of sensory processing at different life stages including during adulthood or aging. Because the serotonergic system influences neural networks throughout the brain, including regions regulating mood and affect, these findings could also serve as a basis for exploring the effects of isolation on affective aspects of the perception of social signals.  

Broader impacts: In addition to these scientific outcomes, this project supported outreach to 9th and 12th grade Biology classrooms in Bloomington, Indiana, as part of the ?Paying it Forward? program. This involved undergraduate students from an Animal Behavior class at Indiana University in designing activities for the high school students related to the sensory abilities of animals. In these activities, scientific method was emphasized. The 9th grade students practiced observation, hypothesis-building, and assessing outcomes. The 12th grade students designed and executed their own small experiments. In the first year of the pandemic, Animal Behavior students designed online activities, assisting teachers in the transition to online learning.
